awd_titl_txt: Troubleshooting and Safety Simulator for Wind Turbine Technician Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will address two critical national issues in community college wind energy technical education: 1) a lack of qualified entry-level technicians in the growing wind energy industry; and 2) the limited ability of students to transfer learned concepts from the classroom to actual applications. The U.S. Department of Energy's Wind Vision report details a plan for 35% of the nation's electrical capacity to come from wind by 2050, which will require over 3,000 new wind technicians each year for the next 15 years.  Moreover, many new wind turbine technicians lack the skills of working safely and effective troubleshooting due to ineffective, outdated, teaching materials.  Through a partnership of community colleges, universities and industry, teaching practices in community college wind energy programs will be transformed using engaging, dynamic content and realistic simulations.  This project will have direct positive impact on over 500 community college students. Broader impacts will include: 1) providing a better-prepared skilled and diverse workforce to meet the demand of the wind energy industry; 2) improving the effectiveness of technology education; 3) providing a model for workforce development in other fields, and 4) inspiring K-12 students in STEM education.  

The project team will develop a web-based interactive 3D simulator incorporating numerous scenarios and education modules based on real world situations. The simulator will be designed to meet specific learning objectives with activities to facilitate learning. It will be used to teach troubleshooting and safety strategies that enable students to solve problems in a safe, cost-effective and timely context. These learning modules will include open-ended questions for students to learn critical thinking and problem solving skills. The simulator will be used in existing community college courses. The effectiveness of the simulator and derivative formats for improving the learning outcomes will be continuously assessed, and such formative assessment throughout the project will enable cyclical improvements. The project will contribute to the body of knowledge on the effectiveness, perceptions, and attitudes regarding web-based interactive 3D simulators for technical education and also measure the learning that comes from the different formats (web-based interactive 3D simulator, videos, and text-based materials). An expected outcome of this project is that computer-based simulators will be increasingly used in the future for transferring learned concepts to practical applications. The simulator will be taught and assessed in four community colleges. The project outcomes can be used by community colleges all over the nation.

por.por_cntn:
Troubleshooting and Safety Simulator for Wind Turbine Technician Education was a project aimed at bridging the gap between community college classrooms and the real world issues encountered by wind turbine technicians (aka "wind techs") working on wind farms. The project produced an interactive 3D simulator software and learning modules for community college students to virtually experience the life of a wind tech and learn about relevant skills associated with troubleshooting (such as reading schematics, working with electrical, mechanical, and hydraulic systems, and safety procedures). The simulator was piloted at partner community colleges in multiple courses ranging from general electrical maintenance up through specific renewable energy and wind turbine troubleshooting courses.

Specific findings related to intellectual merit included:

Findings from the evaluator's report:

  • Students scored an average of about 7% higher in post-testing than they did in pre-testing, with lower standard deviation in the post-test, indicating positive impact
    • The increase was higher for students on the lower end of the range typically than for students that scored higher to begin with in the pre-test
  • The students showed a general positive response to the 3D visualization being included
    • The perceived learning impact of the 3D utilization was good, with most reporting that it kept them from getting bored during activities with the simulator
    • While not as high as the perceived impact, the ratings for different features of the software and User Interface were also good
    • Students rated that it generally helped link some classroom knowledge to new knowledge through the simulator
    • Average student response was very middle of the road (Neither agree nor disagree) on whether it helps them with learning troubleshooting, with most responses either being positive or negative
    • Almost every student agreed or strongly agreed that they?d like to use 3D visualizations and technologies more in the future for other topics as well

Broader impacts of the project included:

  • Presentations using the wind turbine simulator at Ivy Tech at their Energy Day, a high school recruiting event held on-campus
  • Outreach to Minnesota high schools through Riverland Community College using the wind turbine simulator as an activity
  • Presentations and video demonstrations of the simulator to middle school and summer camps at Purdue Northwest, as well as local groups like NIPSCO and OneRegion

In addition, Industry collaborators found the simulator to be useful for already-hired wind techs, and are interested in developing the simulator and modules further for more specific cases encountered in the field. Some specific topics that came up through the course of the project would be application of using VR for virtual turbine tours, blade repair and inspection, application of the troubleshooting aspects for substation training, addition of solar energy and solar energy modules, and possibly the creation of a workbook to use with the simulator to structure it for curriculum.

The simulator can be accessed at windenergy.education or through pnw.edu/civs/wind.
